name: NodeValidatorBuilder
comment:
Class which helps construct standard node validation policies.

By default this will not accept anything, but the 'allow*' functions can be used to expand what types of elements or attributes are allowed.

All allow functions are additive- elements will be accepted if they are accepted by any specific rule.

It is important to remember that sanitization is not just intended to prevent cross-site scripting attacks, but also to prevent information from being displayed in unexpected ways. For example something displaying basic formatted text may not expect <video> tags to appear. In this case an empty NodeValidatorBuilder with just dart-dom-html.NodeValidatorBuilder.allowTextElements might be appropriate.

common.name: common
common.comment:
Creates a new NodeValidatorBuilder which accepts common constructs.

By default this will accept HTML5 elements and attributes with the default dart-dom-html.UriPolicy and templating elements.

Notable syntax which is filtered:

  • Only known-good HTML5 elements and attributes are allowed.

  • All URLs must be same-origin, use dart-dom-html.NodeValidatorBuilder.allowNavigation and dart-dom-html.NodeValidatorBuilder.allowImages to specify additional URI policies.

  • Inline-styles are not allowed.
  • Custom element tags are disallowed, use dart-dom-html.NodeValidatorBuilder.allowCustomElement.
  • Custom tags extensions are disallowed, use dart-dom-html.NodeValidatorBuilder.allowTagExtension.
  • SVG Elements are not allowed, use dart-dom-html.NodeValidatorBuilder.allowSvg.

For scenarios where the HTML should only contain formatted text dart-dom-html.NodeValidatorBuilder.allowTextElements is more appropriate.

Use dart-dom-html.NodeValidatorBuilder.allowSvg to allow SVG elements.

allowNavigation.name: allowNavigation
allowNavigation.comment:
Allows navigation elements- Form and Anchor tags, along with common attributes.

The UriPolicy can be used to restrict the locations the navigation elements are allowed to direct to. By default this will use the default dart-dom-html.UriPolicy.

allowImages.name: allowImages
allowImages.comment:
Allows image elements.

The UriPolicy can be used to restrict the locations the images may be loaded from. By default this will use the default dart-dom-html.UriPolicy.

allowTextElements.name: allowTextElements
allowTextElements.comment:
Allow basic text elements.

This allows a subset of HTML5 elements, specifically just these tags and no attributes.

  • B
  • BLOCKQUOTE
  • BR
  • EM
  • H1
  • H2
  • H3
  • H4
  • H5
  • H6
  • HR
  • I
  • LI
  • OL
  • P
  • SPAN
  • UL

allowInlineStyles.name: allowInlineStyles
allowInlineStyles.comment:
Allow inline styles on elements.

If dart-dom-html.NodeValidatorBuilder.allowInlineStyles.tagName is not specified then this allows inline styles on all elements. Otherwise tagName limits the styles to the specified elements.

allowHtml5.name: allowHtml5
allowHtml5.comment:
Allow common safe HTML5 elements and attributes.

This list is based off of the Caja whitelists at: https://code.google.com/p/google-caja/wiki/CajaWhitelists.

Common things which are not allowed are script elements, style attributes and any script handlers.

allowSvg.name: allowSvg
allowSvg.comment: Allow SVG elements and attributes except for known bad ones.

allowCustomElement.name: allowCustomElement
allowCustomElement.comment:
Allow custom elements with the specified tag name and specified attributes.

This will allow the elements as custom tags (such as <x-foo></x-foo>), but will not allow tag extensions. Use dart-dom-html.NodeValidatorBuilder.allowTagExtension to allow tag extensions.

allowTagExtension.name: allowTagExtension
allowTagExtension.comment:
Allow custom tag extensions with the specified type name and specified attributes.

This will allow tag extensions (such as <div is="x-foo"></div>), but will not allow custom tags. Use dart-dom-html.NodeValidatorBuilder.allowCustomElement to allow custom tags.

allowTemplating.name: allowTemplating
allowTemplating.comment:
Allow templating elements (such as <template> and template-related attributes.

This still requires other validators to allow regular attributes to be bound (such as dart-dom-html.NodeValidatorBuilder.allowHtml5).

add.name: add
add.comment:
Add an additional validator to the current list of validators.

Elements and attributes will be accepted if they are accepted by any validators.

allowsElement.name: allowsElement
allowsElement.comment: Returns true if the tagName is an accepted type.

allowsAttribute.name: allowsAttribute
allowsAttribute.comment:
Returns true if the attribute is allowed.

The attributeName parameter will always be in lowercase.

See dart-dom-html.NodeValidatorBuilder.allowsElement for format of tagName.

hashCode.name: hashCode
hashCode.comment:
Get a hash code for this object.

All objects have hash codes. Hash codes are guaranteed to be the same for objects that are equal when compared using the equality operator ==. Other than that there are no guarantees about the hash codes. They will not be consistent between runs and there are no distribution guarantees.

If a subclass overrides dart-dom-html.NodeValidatorBuilder.hashCode it should override the equality operator as well to maintain consistency.

runtimeType.name: runtimeType
runtimeType.comment: A representation of the runtime type of the object.

==.comment:
The equality operator.

The default behavior for all dart-core.Objects is to return true if and only if this and dart-dom-html.NodeValidatorBuilder.==.other are the same object.

Override this method to specify a different equality relation on a class. The overriding method must still be an equivalence relation. That is, it must be:

  • Total: It must return a boolean for all arguments. It should never throw or return null.

  • Reflexive: For all objects o, o == o must be true.

  • Symmetric: For all objects o1 and o2, o1 == o2 and o2 == o1 must either both be true, or both be false.

  • Transitive: For all objects o1, o2, and o3, if o1 == o2 and o2 == o3 are true, then o1 == o3 must be true.

The method should also be consistent over time, so equality of two objects should not change over time, or at least only change if one of the objects was modified.

If a subclass overrides the equality operator it should override the dart-dom-html.NodeValidatorBuilder.hashCode method as well to maintain consistency.

toString.name: toString
toString.comment: Returns a string representation of this object.

noSuchMethod.name: noSuchMethod
noSuchMethod.comment:
dart-dom-html.NodeValidatorBuilder.noSuchMethod is invoked when users invoke a non-existent method on an object. The name of the method and the arguments of the invocation are passed to dart-dom-html.NodeValidatorBuilder.noSuchMethod in an dart-core.Invocation. If dart-dom-html.NodeValidatorBuilder.noSuchMethod returns a value, that value becomes the result of the original invocation.

The default behavior of dart-dom-html.NodeValidatorBuilder.noSuchMethod is to throw a dart-core.NoSuchMethodError.

allowsElement.name: allowsElement
allowsElement.comment: Returns true if the tagName is an accepted type.

allowsAttribute.name: allowsAttribute
allowsAttribute.comment:
Returns true if the attribute is allowed.

The attributeName parameter will always be in lowercase.

See dart-dom-html.NodeValidatorBuilder.allowsElement for format of tagName.
